1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Brianna

choices: Three loves ones waiting for me
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
I relaxed immediately, enjoying watching the show. Kelly cuddled up to me, whispering "I love you Ally, no matter what!" I beamed at her as my eyes become heavy. It was as if I was in a haze. I could hear voices around me, worried voices. It felt like I was having a weird dream or something. Light flickered on and off as I just stayed still. I woke up in an unfamiliar room. I looked around and Kelly, Aaron and my Dad asleep on chairs. I was in the hospital, again. "Ally?" whispered a hazy Kelly.

Kelly's eyes were red as if she had been crying. "Kelly...what happened?" I asked. "You...you passed out, after we kissed again. I called the hospital immediately. The paramedics were there quick enough to get you out of there. I was so scared! I love you Ally! I love you!" cried Kelly, hugging me tightly. "I love you too, Kelly! What about Patrick? Did Rose help her become a guy again?" I asked. "Sorry sweetie, I don't understand!" she answered. "Didn't Patrick's girlfriend Brianna call us because she accidentally turned Patrick into a girl?" I enquired, worriedly.

“Honey, you have clearly been on some very strong drugs! I don’t know who Brianna is, but I can tell you that Patrick is still a guy!” explained Kelly. “B-But we went to his house! We found out that he was dating Brianna Wallace, his new date to prom! Aaron is now dating Amber and….wait, none of that is real?” I squealed. “I’m afraid not, sweetie!” she replied. “Do…Does Aaron know?” I stammered. She nodded. “I told him that I kissed you and you passed out. I admitted I am still in love with you. He took it....less than spectacularly, though he blames me rather than you! He...suggested that I might have exploited you!"

"But you didn't! I..." "Honey, relax!" she declared, kissing me again. I relaxed against her touch. "Sleep now, my darling!" she exclaimed as I felt weariness take over me and closed my eyes again. When I opened up the next morning....
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: watching Arrow

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"I can't believe I just did that."

That was all I could think about as the boy left the stairwell. As a boy I never had much luck with girls, so I should have understood where this boy was coming from. And yet, here I was, now a girl, doing the same thing to this boy.
I didn't want to make him feel bad, I just didn't feel like being in a relationship considering my predicament; I mean would you if you were a boy who has suddenly been changed into a girl?
Just as he was about to exit my view however, for some reason, maybe out of impulse, the word "Wait..." slipped out of my mouth.

I don't know what I was thinking, but what I did know was that I was standing silent as the boy's face turned towards me.

"Look.... I... uh..." I mumbled quiestly

I breathe in and out quick as I make a decision.

"I.... I'll go on a date with you" I said as I look at the boy, who was looking surprised and confuses.

"Really?" The boy said, "I mean, I thought you said that.."

"I know what I said," I cut him off, "but I didn't really mean it". I did actually mean it, but I didn't want him to know that I was only doing this out of pity for him. "I only said that because.... because I anxious, that's all" I lie, "I am still trying to come to terms with my new sex, and when you asked me out it felt so sudden. I didn't know how to respond.". I come down closer to the boy as I said this. The boy however didn't seem entirely convinced

"Look I don't want you to go out with me because you feel sorry for me, ok" the boy said, "If you really want to go out with me, then I'll deal with it". Just as he was about to walk off again, I impulsively grab hold of his hand. The boy stops and turns back to me, wondering what I was about to do.

"Look into my eyes" I tell him as I stare into his.

I then say firmly and confidently "I want to go on a date with you".
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: It's a Date...  I guess...

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
I fell asleep with Aaron's words echoing in my mind "... starting to think like a girl...". My dream was unpleasant: I dreamed I was being assaulted, restrained, and physically controlled against my will into being girly by various feminine things. It was all a blur; and I soon woke up in a cold sweat.

Checking the clock, I saw it was midnight, but I knew I wouldn't be able to get back to sleep. And...something just felt wrong. I remembered Aaron's words from earlier about "... starting to think like a girl...", and it hit me. I wasn't acting like myself. Sam and Kelly had been helpful in trying to get me to adjust to being a girl, but by going along with it so easily, I wasn't acting like myself. Why had I gotten that dress? Why did I get those accessories? I didn't want them; I had just been talked into it by the salesgirl. Why did I let Sam and Kelly get me skirts and dresses I had no intention of wearing? Why did I let them get me a bikini when I could have insisted on a one-piece swimsuit?

Making a decision, I spent a couple hours gathering together all the feminine stuff I had gotten and been given, except the basest necessities, and put them together in a large box, which I put downstairs, and marked "To get rid of". All the makeup and other cosmetics went straight into the garbage; and the diary Aaron got me went onto the bookshelf. Finally, the feminine products that were absolutely necessary, that I couldn't get rid of, were put away in the bathroom in an empty drawer (which I labeled "Ally") so I'd only see them when necessary.

Finally satisfied, I went back to my room, only to find Aaron waiting. "Ally?" he asked, "What are you doing?" I smiled gently and sat on the bed next to him.

"You were right," I said. "I didn't realize it, but I was letting others convince me into acting like a girl and I hate it. It's just not me. I...I'm a girl physically but I'm still me, and I think I was forgetting that. But not anymore. I got rid of the girly stuff and everything. I'm still me, and I'm not going to let this change who I am. I can just be a tomboy so I can still be myself; I won't be a girly-girl, not ever." I knew as I spoke that I meant every word. Being a girly-girl was not something I could ever be, and if I had to be a girl I would much, much rather be a tomboy. I resolved to tell Sam and Kelly that the next time I saw them; I appreciated their support, but I just could not be a girly-girl.

Meanwhile, Aaron seemed to accept my explanation. "I'm glad you came to your senses, Ally," he said. "You just seemed...not you. I'm glad you're still yourself." And with that settled, we both went back to bed. Having finalized my decision to not be girly, and having gotten rid of the girly stuff, I felt better, and slept easier.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: That night...

1111111111111111111111111112.content:
Kelly put in some romantic comedy, it sucked so I went downstairs for a drink. I looked outside and saw dad talking to the neighbors from next door.

Our neighbors are really religious, so they speak up about everything wrong. They seemed to be in a fight today. "It's unholy!" the dad yelled. " It's unnatural!"

"Leave my daughter out of this!" Dad yelled.

"That's no daughter! It's the devil's work!" the wife yelled. " Born a boy, stays a boy!".

Saddened I ran back to my room. I walked straight into the bathroom to cry myself out. But, Kelly was just about to step into the shower.

Brian felt himself whispering,"She's hot," as he walked out.
1111111111111111111111111112.title: The Sleepover

choices: Yes, that's correct. No sane man wants to be like you.
Calm down, I wouldn't think that.
1111111111111111111112.content:
Does he think I'm a complete imbecile? If he can transplant female organs, he can obviously transplant male ones. Heck, it would have been infinitely easier to do that in the first place than going through the life threatening procedures of altering my bone structure, etc. How dare them treat me like some sort of test subject. And naturally, my idiotic father just let it happen.

"Aaron," I said.

"Yes?" he replied.

"We really should talk to Dad about moving from this city. Every single person seems to know about me, it's disgusting. I can only imagine how bad it'll be at school. Adults for the most part are good at hiding their disdain and disgust. Teenagers like us on the other-hand will take every opportunity to sneer at me," I explained.

"You're overreacting, it won't be that bad. Everyone liked you there..." he said.

"Oh, yes. They did. But, this is High School, you idiot. Popular people fall from grace and are treated no better than trash all the time. It's eat or be eaten, and I'm not plain enough to sit on the sidelines. I'm Freak #1," I explained further, "I can guarantee that in that place. Within three weeks, I'll probably end up starting cutting my wrists or some nonsense. It seems like just the thing to push me over the edge. Thanks to that idiot for a father, I'm right on that edge."

"You have a point, but... Surely, we can stop that from happening..." he was about to say.

"How? Do you remember how many people shot their brains out, took pills or slit their wrists? The school couldn't care less. In fact, it's been a bit of an open secret for years that they know about the extreme bullying, but they willing look the other way," I said.

"Surely, there's something that we can do," he said.

"If I'm going to be the freak of the school, I might as well just end it right here. You have already destroyed my life. Do you want to destroy what little remains of my sanity too? Is that what it'll take to satisfy you? Yes. You enjoy it, don't you? Every-day, you probably sneer at me and breathe a sigh of relief that it wasn't you," I ranted.
1111111111111111111112.title: Smarter than one might expect

11111111111112.content:
Melissa left my room a few minutes later to be with the other guests. I decided to stay in my room, however. I just didn't feel like dealing with all these people at once, knowing it would only lead to awkward conversations. I didn't know how I felt about Melissa's proposal either. Being a bridesmaid isn't something I was ready to do, and I was tempted to say no, but then I reminded myself that the wedding was months away. I'd probably never be a girly girl, but hopefully by that point the mere idea of wearing a dress wouldn't make me sick. Also, Melissa had always been there for me, whenever I needed someone to talk to who was mature without being my father. I couldn't possibly refuse her that.

I don't know how long I sat there, trying to fall asleep, without success due to all the noise from downstairs. All these people didn't seem to mind that I wasn't there with them. It's hard to tell whether they realized I needed to be alone or if they just didn't care. I decided on the former. Suddenly, I heard footsteps going up the stairs, followed by two voices.

"Are you sure she won't hear?" Dad's voice asked.

"Yeah, she said she was tired, that she'd go to bed early." Aaron replied. "She must be asleep by now."

He was partially right. If I wasn't asleep, it wasn't for lack of trying. Knowing that they didn't want me to hear this only made me more interested. Getting up as quietly as I could, I walked to the door and pressed my ear against it.

"So how do we break it to her?" Aaron asked.

"We just tell her directly. It's for her own good, she'll understand."

"Jesus Christ, Dad! Ally's not stupid, but there's no way she's gonna be okay with that! We erased her entire life. No more Brian, that guy never existed, and you think she's just going to accept that?"

"She'll be angry at first, but it was necessary. She'll forgive me eventually."

"Yeah, I have doubts about that..."

I'd heard enough. I didn't even know what exactly they'd done, but I knew it wasn't good. They erased the person I use to be. They forced me into becoming Allison without even giving me a choice. And I wasn't going to stand for that. A few tears streamed down my face as I opened my window. There's a tree right next to it that I always used to climb down whenever I wanted to get out without Dad knowing. As silently as I could, I jumped through the window and grabbed on to the tree. Then, I began my descent.

I just ran, I don't know for how long. I eventually reached a park that I'd never been to, and sat on a bench, before breaking down into tears. They never even gave me a choice! To them, it didn't matter how I felt, they just decided everything for me. Well it didn't matter to me if it was for my own good. I had a right to make my own choices.

After a while, a car stopped nearby. I recognized it as Melissa's car. Sure enough, Melissa got out of the car and sat right next to me.

"So that's where you've been!" she said, relieved. "Everybody's looking for you. We thought you might have..."

"Don't worry about me." I replied. "I'm just... really pissed."

"I understand that."

"No you don't! I've lost everything! My own family made sure to erase all traces of my existence. My entire life has been literally destroyed!"

"I know this is hard for you, but you have to go back home. It's not safe for a girl to wander alone at night."

"I'm not a girl! And I'm not going back there. Not with... them."

"It's still not safe out here. Listen, if you can't deal with your family, you're welcome to come home with me."

"That... that'd be better. Thanks, Melissa."

"Alright, just let me make a phone call."

She pulled out her cell phone and dialed a number I recognized as my father's.

"I found her... Yeah, she's safe... No... No, she doesn't want to come back... I know... She'll stay at my apartment for now... Alright. Bye." She hung up. "It's okay. Your dad's worried, but he'll let you stay with me for now."

"Thanks. I hope I'm not too much trouble."

"Of course not. I have more than enough room. You're welcome to stay with me as long as you want. Now get in the car, it's getting cold out here."

I followed Melissa into her car. We both stayed silent for a few minutes, as she drove toward her apartment, but she eventually broke the silence.

"Listen, Ally." I cringed at the name. "I know you don't want to be a girl, but you can't keep denying it either. You're a girl now. Your name is Allison, and that's not going to change."

"I know."

"I'll do my best to help you adjust. Frankly, I'll probably do a much better job of it than your dad would. But you've got to work with me, alright?"

"I'll try. Just... nothing too girly, okay?"

"Well, I can't promise you that. You see..." She stopped when she noticed my frown. "Okay, I promise. Nothing to girly."
11111111111112.title: Betrayal

111111111111121.content:
As close I was to Melissa, I'd never been to her apartment before. I always talked to her on the internet, or whenever she'd come visit us. As I entered, I found that it was small, but nice.

"Sorry, I didn't know I'd have a visitor, so I didn't clean up." Melissa said.

That's Melissa in a nutshell. She's always been a bit of a neat freak.

"No, it's fine." I replied. "It's not dirty at all."

"Thanks. Well, I'll give you the tour. This is the living room. The TV's here. Oh, and the couch is actually a futon, so that's where you'll be sleeping." She then pointed at the left side of the room. "There's the kitchen. I know it's actually part of the living room, but... Don't hesitate to grab something from the fridge if you're hungry. That door over there leads to the bathroom." Then, she pointed to a door right across the room. "And that's my bedroom. No one gets in here but me. I'm serious, not even my fiance... I like to have my privacy. Sooo, that's pretty much everything. I know it's small, but..."

"It's fine. Really. So, you're sure you don't mind me staying here?"

"How many times do I have to say it? You can stay here until the wedding if you want, it's a pleasure to help."

"Okay. Thanks Melissa. I don't know what I'd do without you."

"Well, you'll be completely lost that's for sure." She looked at me, noticing I came empty-handed. "If you're planning on staying here for more than one night, it might be a good idea to go back to your house and grab some of your clothes."

"I kind of don't have any clothes. Dad was supposed to take me shopping tomorrow, but it looks like that's not gonna happen, so..."

"I'll take you shopping. Besides, who would you rather have help you choose clothes, me or your dad?"

I chuckled. And then I looked down. "I just don't have any money."

"Not a problem. It's on me."

"You know I need an entire wardrobe, right?"

"I know, and my offer still stands. Unless of course you'd rather go ask your dad for money."

"Good point... Anyway, I think I'll go to bed early. I'm really tired."

"No problem. You can use the shower if you want. I'll set up the futon for you."

"Okay, thanks."

I went to the bathroom and started taking off my clothes. I then got in the shower and started cleaning myself up. During the past few days, I'd gotten used to having a female body. I didn't like the idea, but it didn't constantly bother me. But now, it angered me. It reminded me of how I was never given a choice. How Dad had erased the person I was from the face of the world without even asking me. I just wanted to finish this and go to bed as soon as possible. I think at some point I heard the door open and close, but I didn't really pay attention to it. I finally got out of the shower and noticed some pajamas laying, neatly folded, on the floor. From the looks of it, they were the least feminine pajamas Melissa could find in her wardrobe. After drying myself, I slipped into the pajamas. They weren't a perfect it fit, as I was an inch taller than Melissa, while she was slightly bustier than me, but thankfully they were loose enough to be comfortable.

Gathering my clothes, I exited the bathroom to see that Melissa had already set up the futon and put some blankets on it. As I walked towards the makeshift bed, Melissa got out of her own bedroom.

"Well, I'm going to got to bed too." she said. "So, have a good night."

"Thanks, you too."

While Melissa went back into her bedroom, I got into bed and quickly fell asleep.
111111111111121.title: New Home

1111111111111211.content:
"Good morning, Ally! Time to get up." Melissa said, cheerfully.

"Do I have to?" I asked, still half asleep. "I'm still tired..."

"It's almost eleven, so yes, you have to. Besides, today's gonna be fun. We're going shopping!"

"Don't remind me. I hate shopping."

"You're way too negative, Ally. I'm sure you'll get some enjoyment out of it. Sure beats sitting around here brooding."

"Yeah, I guess you're right..."

"Besides, you don't have a choice. I washed the outfit you wore yesterday, but you'll need more clothes than that, and you'll never fit into mine."

She was right, I definitely needed clothes. But I always hated shopping. How can girls spend hours doing that? I decided that I'd go along with it, for the sake of necessity. Who knows, I might even enjoy it... Just a little... Actually, the entire experience would probably turn out to be pure torture. I quickly got up and dressed.

"So, um, are we going now?" I asked.

"Are you crazy?" Melissa said, staring at me like she'd seen a ghost. "You can't go out like that. Look at yourself!"

Melissa grabbed my hand and dragged me into the bathroom, where she placed me in front of the mirror. I saw the same reflection I'd seen for the past few days: a normal girl, with more than a passing resemblance to the boy I used to be.

"Yeah, that is my reflection. So what?" I asked.

"So what? Your hair is a mess! If you won't fix it yourself, at least let me take care of it."

I gave myself a good look. Melissa was right: my shoulder-length brown hair was a complete mess. I hadn't paid any attention to it earlier, but now that Melissa had mentioned it, it was hard to take my eyes away from it.

"Okay, you can fix my hair. I don't have a clue how to do it."

Melissa grabbed a comb and started working on my hair. For some reason, it felt like she was actually enjoying it. I sure wasn't, though. However, when she was done, I could tell that I looked a lot more attractive. Not that I wanted to, but I wasn't going to complain either.

"There, perfect." Melissa started. "Now maybe a hint of makeup."

"Don't push your luck." I replied.

"Relax, Ally, I'm just messing with you. Now come on, let's put a smile on that pretty face of yours. It's not good to be grumpy all the time."

There was something about Melissa's attitude that really helped cheer me up, even though she could be annoying sometimes. I couldn't help but oblige when she asked me to smile.

"There, much better. Now let's go."

I followed Melissa into her car, and we left for the mall.
1111111111111211.title: Good Morning

11111111111112111.content:
Melissa and I were at the mall's food court, eating our lunches before getting started on the shopping. Melissa had gotten a salad while I was eating a burger.

"You'll get fat if you keep eating stuff like that, Ally." Melissa said.

"Do I look like I care?" I replied, before taking another bite. Not liking the sound of my own reply, I quickly swallowed before adding: "Mel, I know you mean well, but you have to remember that I'm a guy. I doesn't matter that I look like a girl, you can't just ask me to think like one. Besides, it's just one burger, it can't be that bad."

"I'm just looking out for you. You said it yourself, you don't know anything about being a girl. I'm here to teach you these things."

"I know that, but maybe we should stick to the basics. You know, stuff that's necessary to my survival. I don't plan on letting this change everything about my life."

"I guess you're right. Let's just finish this and get started on the shopping. Where do you want to go first?"

"I have no idea."

"Alright, then let's get the boring stuff out of the way first. We'll buy you some hygiene products, and then some underwear, and then we'll start getting you some outfits. I just need to call your Dad first." Melissa said, grabbing her cell phone.

"I don't want to talk to him."

"I know, I know. I'll take care of this. I just need some information."

She dialed Dad's number and raised the phone to her ear. "Hello... Yeah, it's Melissa. Listen, I'm at the mall with Ally and... No, it's okay, I'm taking care of that... Alright, thanks. I just need to know something. Would you happen to have Ally's measurements? I need to know what size she'll wear... Okay, thanks. Bye." She hung up. "Thankfully, your doctor took your measurements and gave them to your Dad. He's gonna email them to me, so that should spare you some embarrassment."

"Good to know. I wouldn't want to ask some store employee for my bra size" I said, before taking the last bite of my burger.

"That's what I was thinking. Now I'm guessing you don't want to spend your entire day here, so let's get started."

The first thing we did was get me a few hygiene products. Shampoo, deodorant, that king of thing. At first I wasn't sure about buying girl products, stuff that smells like flowers, until I figured that I didn't really care what I smell like. We then moved on to getting me some new underwear. Thankfully, Melissa having received the email from Dad, I didn't need to try them on.

"So, what kind of underwear do you want to wear?"

"You mean there are different kinds?"

"Oookay. Let's do this differently. Just pick some that you think look good."

"Does it really matter? I just want something that's not too girly. Is there a 'regular underwear' option?"

"Alright, never mind. I'll pick for you."

Melissa proceeded to select multiple sets of bras and panties. She apparently listen to what I said, as most of what she picked was white and plain. She still chose a few that were a little too frilly for my tastes, but I didn't complain, since at least I didn't have to do it myself. After paying, we moved on to the next item on the list.

Melissa insisted that I needed new shoes, despite the obvious fact that I already had some on my feet. She managed to convince me however, by saying that running shoes aren't appropriate for more formal events. At least she didn't insist on buying a thousand different pair. Since I was still not really interested, I let her pick some sandals and a pair of dress shoes, which, to my dismay, turned out to be high heels.

After a trip to the car to drop off some of our purchases, Melissa decided that we needed to talk.

"Ally, I know shopping is not your thing, but you could at least give me some input. Right now, you're just letting me pick everything."

"I'm just not really interested in this. You're asking me to actively participate in choosing underwear and shoes. No one even cares about that stuff!"

"You'd be surprised... Still, now we're going to buy you some actual outfits. Maybe you could be a little more enthusiastic? I'm not asking you to like this, but at least try to help me choose. You're the one who's going to wear these clothes. Try to find some outfits you like, or at least tell me what kind of clothes you want."

"Okay, I'll try..."

"Thanks. And maybe if you participate more, you won't find it so boring."

I wasn't so sure about that, but she still made a few good points. We headed back into the mall.
11111111111112111.title: First Shopping Experience

111111111111121111.content:
As soon as we were back in the mall, Melissa and I headed straight to a clothes store. I didn't bother checking the name of the place, but Melissa said she went there all the time. We quickly started shopping; Melissa selecting clothes, and me giving my approval. Or my disapproval, actually. Melissa seemed hell-bent on choosing clothes that were way too feminine for my taste. We did of course keep a few items, but for half an hour of shopping, it wasn't much.

"What about this one?" Melissa asked, holding a piece of clothing.

"It's a dress."

"Yeah, and?"

"I don't wear dresses."

"This isn't gonna work." a visibly annoyed Melissa stated. "You know, when I said you should participate more, this isn't exactly what I meant. At this rate, we'll be in here forever."

"Then maybe you should just pick all the clothes. I won't complain, I swear." I said, fully aware that I'd probably regret it later.

Melissa paused for a moment. "How about this? We split up, and each of us picks ten item. Then we meet back here. Is that okay with you?"

I nodded, and soon we were in completely different areas of the store. I started going through the pants section. I picked out two pairs of jean, paying more attention to the size than to what they looked like. Since it was still summer, I figured I might need some shorts, too. I skipped over the really short ones and went straight to the knee-length shorts, picking out two pairs. I then moved on to the tops, selecting several t-shirts of various colors that I thought looked good. Counting the clothes I was holding, I saw that I had reached my quota and headed for the rendez-vous point. Knowing Melissa, she'd probably need a few more minutes.

And need a few more minutes she did. Melissa eventually returned, a pile of clothes in her hands.

"So, was it that hard?" she asked.

"No. I didn't pick anything too feminine, though."

"I didn't expect you to. Well, now it's time to try these on."

"Why? We have a list of my clothes sizes, we already know they'll fit."

"Ally, trying on clothes isn't just about making sure they fit; we also need to make sure they look good on you."

"Okay, fine. Let's just not take too long."

As we made our way to the dressing rooms, Melissa matched the clothes together, choosing the outfits she thought were worth trying on. I entered an empty stall, grabbing the pile of clothes Melissa was handing me before cosing the door. Looking through the clothes, I counted a dozen outfits... four of which were way too girly for me; there even was a dress! Ignoring those for now, I quickly undressed and put on the first outfit: jeans I had picked earlier, along with a black tank top. I wasn't sure about the tank top, but once I was wearing it, it was pretty comfortable. I stepped out of the stall to show Melissa my outfit.

"You look great, Ally!" she said. "Now let's see the next one."

We repeated this process several times, me trying on several outfits and showing them to Melissa, who approved all of them, making me question why I was trying them on instead of just buying them. I mostly went with the more unisex stuff: pants, shorts, various shirts, that sort of thing. It was obvious what Melissa was waiting for.

"It's all good, Ally. Now let's see you in that dress."

"Isn't it a little too girly?" I asked.

"If you keep thinking like that, you'll never get used to being girl. Trust me: it's just a dress, it won't hurt."

"But I..."

"Come on, Ally, just try it on. For me. Please?"

"Alright, I'll do it..."

For some reason, I never could refuse her anything. Melissa always had that way of getting what she wanted just by looking at you. Stepping back into the stall, I held up the dress, examining it in an attempt to delay the moment where I'd have to wear it. It was a yellow, knee-length sundress with spaghetti straps. After taking off my current outfit, I slipped into the dress. It wasn't uncomfortable, actually. Looking in the mirror, I saw that it made me look very cute. There was nothing wrong with the dress per se; but the idea that I was wearing it just felt wrong. Reluctantly, I stepped out of the stall to let Melissa admire the dress.

"Ally, you look adorable." she said, excitingly. "We're buying that dress."

"I don't know, it feels kinda... I don't know, wrong. I'm still a guy inside; I'm not supposed to wear this."

"Here's an idea. Instead of thinking about what you want to wear, maybe you should ask yourself what you'd like to see on a girl. You can't deny that this dress looks great on you."

She had a point. Thinking that way would at least help me buy clothes that'd look good on me. With that thinking, buying that dress was an obvious choice. But still...

"You know I'll probably never wear it again, right?" I asked.

"I'm fine with that."

"Then we can buy this dress if you want."

"Great! Now let's see the rest of these clothes."

Back inside the stall, I was relieved to see that there were only three outfits left. Of course, they were the girliest outfits of the bunch, but after that dress, they didn't seem that bad by comparison. All of them had skirts. And of course, all of them were promptly approved by Melissa.

After paying for our purchases, we headed for the mall's exit. That's when I saw a familiar face: Kelly O'Rourke. She was a girl from school that my brother always had a crush on. She always ignored his advances, but they still got along well, and I got to talk to her several times. She was a nice girl. Almost on reflex, I greeted her.

"Hi, Kelly."

"Hi, uh... Excuse me, but, have we met?" she replied, confused. She proceeded to examine my face. "Wait... Brian Samuels? Is that you?"

I nodded.

"I heard what happened to you... So, how are you holding up?"

"I'm still getting used to being a girl." I answered. "The rest I'd rather not talk about."

"Oh... Well, it was nice seeing you. Glad to see you're out of the hospital... I should go now, I kind of promised Sam I'd meet her, and..."

"It's fine. Nice to see you too."

Well that was awkward. As she walked away, I could feel that Kelly was slightly uneasy around me.

"So, who was that?" Melissa asked.

"Just a girl I know."

"Alright. Are you ready to go?"

"Actually, there's something else I want to do while we're here."
111111111111121111.title: Second Shopping Experience

1111111111111211111.content:
"Come on, Ally, it's time to get up." Melissa said, shaking me.

"Damn... I was having a really nice dream."

"Your dreams can wait. You have school today."

"Alright, alright, I'm coming."

I quickly got up and pulled out a cardboard box from under the futon. Due to a lack of storage space, all of my wardrobe had been stored in boxes under the futon. Not an ideal solution, but it worked. I proceeded to choose an outfit: knee-length jeans and a black spaghetti strap tank top. I would have preferred a standard t-shirt, but over the last two days Melissa insisted that I try wearing skirts. I managed to talk my way out of it both times, but I didn't feel like arguing today, so I instead went for a compromise. Thankfully, Melissa seemed satisfied with my choice of outfit, and it didn't bother me too much.

I got in and out of the shower as fast as I could, before getting dressed and fixing my now shorter hair. Back at the mall, I decided to have my hair cut. Of course, Melissa didn't think it was a good idea, but we finally agreed on the chin length bob cut I now sported. I originally wanted even shorter than that, but Melissa made a few good points against it, and I had to admit that she was right. Besides, this style kinda grew on me: it looks good and is easy to maintain.

After a quick breakfast, Melissa and I were in the car, driving towards the school. I had to admit that I was nervous. I was going back to school as a girl, and it was a safe bet to assume that a lot of students already knew about my condition. Part of me felt like they were going to laugh at me, even though I knew it probably wouldn't be the case. However, they would ask me a lot of awkward questions or avoid me like the plague. Either way, I wouldn't have many friends. Sure, Patrick and Eric would be there, but they'd be a grade above me. There was Aaron, too, but I didn't want to deal with him at the moment. I'd probably spend most of the day alone, trying to avoid lots of unwanted attention.

"How do you feel, Ally?" Melissa asked.

"Just nervous, that's all. I'm not sure how the other students will react to me."

"I'm not going to lie to you. Some of them will be mean to you. Most of them probably won't care, though. They'll leave you alone after a few days."

"I hope so. I'm not planning on being the center of attention."

"Well, you better be ready, because we're here."

It took me a few seconds to realize that the car had been stopped for the last minute. Sighing, I got out and started walking towards the school, while Melissa took off. She worked as a teacher at the elementary school two blocks away, so I knew she wouldn't be far if I needed her. I rapidly disappeared into the flow of other students pouring into the high school. Right back into a teenager's personal hell.
1111111111111211111.title: Back into Hell

11111111111112111111.content:
I was going with the flow, dragged by the seemingly infinite crowd of students through the high school. Almost miraculously, I managed to spot two familiar faces and started pushing my way to them, while cursing myself for not waiting until the mob dissipated before entering the school. With much effort, I finally reached my targets.

"Damn, it feels like a zombie apocalypse in here. Right, guys?"

"Yep, it sure does. I've always said that high school students have much in common with the living dead." Eric said. "But, um... Who are you again?"

"Dude, you're joking, right?"

"Nope, I think he's serious." Patrick said.

"You know this girl?"

"Oh, for God's sake... It's Ally!"

While I resisted the urge to slam my palm against my forehead, Eric stared at me wide-eyed. After about three seconds, he finally got it; I could almost see the light bulb over his head.

"So... You got a new haircut! And new clothes!"

"And you have a great sense of observation!" I replied, sarcastically. "How the hell did you not recognize me?"

"I'm not very good with faces. Honestly, I kind of expected you to look exactly the same as three days ago."

"I hate to interrupt this very important conversation, but can I talk to you in private, Ally?"

"Um, yeah. Sure."

"Well, uh... I'll just stay right here with the zombie crowd." Eric quietly said as I followed Patrick into an empty corridor.

Once we had reached quiet area, Patrick looked at me. He seemed very serious, and a little frustrated.

"What are you doing, Ally?" he asked.

"Well, I'm at school, obviously, and right now I'm talking to you. Got any other stupid questions?"

"You know what I mean. You disappear for days and don't call anyone, and now you're acting like nothing happened. Well it doesn't work like that!"

"I'm staying at my cousin's apartment. I assumed Aaron would have told you."

"Yeah, he did. Yesterday. He also told me that you refused to talk to him or your dad, and that I probably shouldn't bother trying to call you. Now, I'm gonna ask you again: why are you doing this? What is going on?"

"It's none of your business. I know you're worried about me, but this is between me and my family, and I'd appreciate if you don't bring it up again."

"I'm not just going to sit around and pretend everything is okay when clearly it's not. If you want to hide from your problems and cry in a corner, by all means, go ahead. Just don't expect me to watch you do it." Patrick started waking away. After a few steps, he tuned around. "When you want to talk, come see me."

As Patrick went back towards where we left Eric, and away from me, I finally broke down. I just sat there on the floor, tears pouring across my face, as contradicting thoughts fought inside my brain. Part of me agreed with Patrick. He was right: I was just running away, avoiding my problems instead of facing them. But the rest of my mind was screaming that I had every right run away. Had I not suffered enough? Could I really be expected to face my family after what they did? They lied to me, and I clearly wasn't capable of confronting them about it, not after everything that happened before. Sure, I was just hiding, but it was the only thing to do, and I had no obligation to talk to Patrick about it either.
11111111111112111111.title: And It All Comes Crashing Down

111111111111121111111.content:
"Well, there you are." said a slightly familiar female voice.

I couldn't quite remember where I'd heard that voice before. I raised my eyes to see Samantha Peterson, a friend of Kelly. She sat beside me.

"You're Allison Samuels, right? The teacher sent me to get you." Samantha continued. "Classes started fifteen minutes ago... But you look like you're not in the mood for that. Now tell me, what is it? Broke up with your boyfriend or something?"

I almost laughed. "Not even close..."

"Okay, so what... Wait a sec. Your last name is Samuels, right?" she asked. I nodded. "Oh crap... Listen, I'm sorry, I didn't realize that was you. I'm so sorry for what happened to you Brian."

"Just call me Allison. That's what everyone does."

"Do you like that name?"

"Not really. But it's not like I have a choice." I answered. "Look, don't make this more complicated than it already is."

"Okay... Allison. Listen, if you need to talk to anyone..."

"Did I say that?"

"No. You're right, you didn't." Samantha got up. "Well, if you don't want to talk to anyone, I suppose my work here is done. I'll tell the teacher you're not up to attend his class. See you later, Allison."

"Wait!" I said as she started walking away. "I'm sorry... You're right, I need to talk."

I definitely did need to talk. Patrick was right about that, but I certainly wasn't going to crawl back to him. At least, Samantha didn't try to force me to talk, so if someone had to hear what was on my mind, it might as well be her. It was either that, or waiting until I blew up. Samantha came back and sat down next to me again.

"I just can't take this anymore." I started. "I feel like I can't trust anybody anymore."

I told her everything. I told how I overheard Aaron and Dad talking about having destroyed my previous identity and how, unable to deal with them, I ran away. I went over my staying at Melissa's place, and her constant attempts to get me to act more like a girl. And finally, I talked about my fight with Patrick. Samantha didn't say anything. She just listened.

"I-I think that's everything." I said. "Thanks for listening to me."

"Not a problem. I'm happy to help."

"Wait, that's it? You're not gonna tell me that I should forgive everyone or something like that?"

"Nah, I just figured you needed to unload a lot of stuff. I'm not gonna tell you what to do."

Ever since I woke up at the hospital, this was the first time someone said the words 'I'm not gonna tell you what to do' and it was precisely what I needed to hear. I needed to feel that I still had some control over my life. Barely able to hold back tears, I hugged Samantha.

"Thank you, Samantha. I really needed this."

"As I said, I'm happy to help. So, are you ready to go back to class?"

I nodded. We both stood up and started walking through the empty corridors of the school.

"By the way, just call me Sam." Samantha added. "I don't really like my full name either."

"Okay, I'll keep that in mind."

When we entered the classroom, every single student stared at me. A menacing glare from Sam was enough to make them stop, but one of them kept looking at me: Aaron. Avoiding his stare, I quietly walked to my seat and sat down. The teacher continued his lesson, but I wasn't listening; after all, I'd heard all that the year before. I was too busy thinking about what I'd tell my brother when he'd inevitably come talk to me.
111111111111121111111.title: A Friendly Face

1111111111111211111111.content:
The bell rang. As everybody got up to leave the class, I did the same. I had managed to avoid my brother at the end of the first class, but of course he was in the second one as well. Still hoping that Aaron would understand that I didn't want to talk to him, I followed the other students, trying to hide inside the crowd. My hopes were crushed, however, as soon as I crossed the door, as I felt a hand grab my arm and was dragged away from the safety off the crowd. I turned around to see, of course, Aaron.

"Why are you avoiding me?" he asked.

"Why do you think?"

"Honestly, I have no idea. Nice outfit, by the way. You know, you're looking more and more like a girl."

"That was definitely not my intention." I replied, coldly. "When were you going to tell me?"

"Tell you what? You know, Melissa was really unclear over the phone. All she said is that you were severely pissed at me and Dad."

"Have you ever heard about a guy called Brian Samuels? Of course not, because he doesn't even exist anymore! According to all official records, he never existed! I heard you and Dad talking the night I came back home."

"So that's what it's all about?" Sam said, sighing. "I told him it wouldn't end well... Listen, Ally. You have to trust me on this: it was for the best."

"You know what else is for the best? Me, leaving. Now."

Aaron was silent as I walked away. I soon noticed that Sam was still here, laying against the wall. She seemed to be waiting for me.

"Why are you still here?" I asked. "I thought you were having lunch with Kelly and, um... that girl whose name I keep forgetting."

"Amber." Sam replied. "And with what you told me I figured you probably don't have anyone to hang out with at lunch break. So, I thought I'd invite you to join us."

"Really? We barely know each other."

"I know, but you seem like a nice girl... guy... whatever, and you probably need some friends right now. You know, we could be friends, you and I."

"Yeah, we could." I answered. "Alright, I'm coming. I just need to go to my locker to grab my lunch."

Why was Sam so nice to me? We barely ever talked to each other. She was a friend of a casual acquaintance of my brother. There was absolutely no reason for her to feel the need to help me. And yet... Maybe she was simply interested in my case. What better way to examine the boy turned girl than to befriend her? If that was the case, then I was nothing more than a freak, a thing people want to study as a curiosity. Or maybe I was just being paranoid. That seemed more likely. Sam probably just took pity on me. I didn't really like that idea, but I didn't have any friends left either. Better just trust her for now.

Having reached my locker, I grabbed the paper bag containing my lunch and headed to the cafeteria. Looking at the dozens of students already eating, it took me a while to spot Sam's table. Sam spotted me first, actually, and waved her arm to attract my attention. On my way there, I of course just had to pass by Patrick and Eric's table. Patrick simply ignored me, while Eric stared at me questioningly. It was awkward. I finally reached Sam's table, where she, Kelly and Amber had already started eating. As soon as I sat down, Amber stopped me.

"What are you doing?" he asked.

"Uh, I was just..."

"It's okay, Amber." Sam intervened. "I told her she could come here."

"Fine..." Amber replied. It was painfully obvious that she wasn't pleased by my presence.

Thankfully, Kelly's attitude was much more inviting, though still a little awkward. "Hi Ally. Good to see you again." she said. "I uh, I like your new style. You look good."

"Thanks. It's good to see you too."

"Are you still doing okay? With all that's happened to you, and having to adjust to being a girl..."

"I survive. I wouldn't say I'm okay, but I'll manage."

"What difference does it make anyway?" Amber said. "Even if you look like a girl, you're still a guy."

I was tempted to thank her, as she perfectly summed up how I felt, but there was something I didn't like in the way she said it. Kelly didn't seem to notice that detail, but she clearly didn't like the comment itself.

"Her past doesn't matter." Kelly stated. "Ally is a girl, now, just like any of us."

To be honest, Kelly's comment was actually more offensive to me than Amber's. Of course, in that case I knew she didn't mean it as an insult and decided to keep my mouth shut. Sam, however, didn't.

"Can you stop, both of you? Ally can decide if she's a guy or a girl. Either way, there's no use fighting over it."

"I'll just leave, now." Amber said, getting up. "By the way, Ally, you can't decide what gender you are. You're still a guy, so don't bother pretending you're not."

We all sat in silence as Amber walked away.

"Should I go?" I asked. "I don't want to cause any trouble."

"It's okay." Sam said. "Amber didn't really mean it. She's just pissed because she lost the argument. She'll come around."

"Are you sure?"

"Yeah, trust me. I know her."

Relieved, I unpacked my lunch and started eating.
1111111111111211111111.title: Stuck in the Middle

11111111111112111111111.content:
"Hi Ally, how was your day?"

I've always hated that question. When someone asks you that, they never really want an answer; they just expect you to say "fine" and end it there. However, my day was anything but fine: I could probably write a twelve page essay on why it was terrible. And of course, this is Melissa I'm talking about. Put those two together, and I'll spend the next three hours talking about what went wrong, something I must avoid at all cost. So I just went with the easy answer:

"It was fine." I said. "Most of the students just ignored me."

That was a lie, of course: after lunch, my classmates became a lot more interested in me. Thankfully, Sam was there to rescue me before I was overwhelmed.

"Glad to hear it went well." Melissa replied. "Ready to go home?"

"Yeah."

"Ally, wait!"

I turned around to see two girls running towards me: Kelly and Sam. After telling Melissa I wouldn't be long, I went to see them.

"We were wondering if you'd like to go to the mall with us." Kelly said.

"We always go there after school." Sam added. "Either to shop or just hang out."

Needless to say, going to the mall wasn't my favorite activity. I tried to be diplomatic about it. By lying.

"Sorry guys, I can't right now. I already had something planned."

Kelly looked disappointed, but Sam knew I what I really meant. She didn't say anything, though. That's when I realized that they didn't care about going to the mall: they just wanted to include me and let me know that they wanted to be my friends. I felt bad.

"But maybe some other time." I added. "How about tomorrow?"

"Sure. That'd be great!" Kelly answered.

After saying goodbye, I joined Melissa in the car and we left for her apartment.

Later that evening, after we were done eating and washing the dishes, Melissa and I started wondering what we should do for the rest of the day.

"We could watch a movie." Melissa suggested.

"Sure, what do you have?"

"My DVDs are right next to the TV, just pick whatever you want."

I started going through the pile, which turned out to be pretty small. There were about a dozen movies, most of which were chick flicks. There was one, however, that caught my attention.

"You have Scott Pilgrim vs The World?"

"Yeah, I got it at random at a gift exchange last Christmas. Haven't watched it yet." Melissa answered.

"We're watching that."

Just as I was grabbing the DVD box from the pile, the doorbell rang. I put the disc in the DVD player while Melissa went to answer the door. Soon after, I heard the door open.

"I think it's for you, Ally." Melissa said.

For me? Who would come all the way here at this time just to talk to me? If it was Dad or Aaron, I didn't want to talk to them. It couldn't possibly be Patrick. Maybe Kelly and Sam? Nah, they wouldn't come here this late. Then who? I walked to the door, only to see Eric. I joined him outside and closed the door.

"What are you doing here? It's getting pretty late." I said.

"I know, I was supposed to be here a while ago, but then I got lost. Twice."

It wasn't long before my palm hit my forehead. Classic Eric, no sense of direction.

"Okay, and you didn't just call me because?"

"You know I hate phone conversations. You can never really tell what someone is thinking when you can't see their face." Eric explained. "So, what I came here to say is: I'm not with Patrick on this one. Well, he's still my friend, but you're my friend too. We can still hang out, even if Patrick is pissed at you."

"Thanks, I appreciate that."

"Well, you know I don't want to lose you. Neither does Patrick. I don't think he realizes he's not helping. He can be pretty dumb sometimes."

"Yeah, he is. I guess he'll come around, eventually." I said. "Do you think you can get back home on your own, or do you need a map?"

"I'll be fine. I think. Anyway, see you tomorrow at school, Ally."

Eric left, and I went back inside with. Then, I sat down with Melissa and we started the movie.
11111111111112111111111.title: Finally Out

111111111111121111111111.content:
School was pretty uneventful for the first part of the day; I went to my classes without a problem. That was...until lunch. I'd just sat down for lunch with Kelly and Sam, when Amber suddenly appeared. "What do you want, Amber?" Sam coldly asked.

"Calm down, Sam, I'm just here to apologize." Amber replied. "What I said yesterday was out of line, and I'm sorry."

"That's all good, but... I think you're apologizing to the wrong person."

"Oh, right." She turned to face me. "I'm sorry, Ally."

"It's okay. You're forgiven."

I wasn't really sure if I wanted to forgive her, but I did want to avoid unnecessary conflicts. Too late to back down now, anyway: Amber was already sitting down at our table.

"I'm so glad you came back, Amber." Kelly said. "It wouldn't be the same without you."

The conversation soon shifted to more normal topics, some of which I had a hard time getting interested into. I still made an effort to comment once in a while, just for the sake of being part of it. Amber quickly reintegrated the group, which seemed to please Kelly. Sam, on the other hand, didn't seem as thrilled by Amber's return, but she didn't show it too much. Soon, lunchtime was over, and we went back to class.
111111111111121111111111.title: Continue

1111111111111211111111111.content:
"So, this is what you guys do for fun?" I asked the three girls as we walked through the mall.

"Well, yeah." Kelly answered. "I know you probably don't have the shopping gene, since you used to be a boy and all, but trust me, shopping is fun."

"Just relax." Sam said. "Stop telling yourself that it's a girl thing and that you shouldn't be doing it. Maybe you'll even enjoy it."

"And if you don't, well... At least you'll understand girls a little better afterwards." Amber added.

They did have a few good points. Maybe if I looked at things differently I could end up enjoying shopping. I just didn't really see how. To me, shopping has always been that thing I do when I'm almost out of presentable outfits. I just go in, get what I need and get out. The major difference here is that, while I go shopping because I need clothes, these three girls (along with many others), do it for the shopping itself, as if it were actually enjoyable. And now they're asking me to not only understand that, but take part in it as well.

"Look, I'll try. Just don't be surprised if it turns out I don't like it. Remember that I'm not actually supposed to be a girl."

I could have sworn I saw a grin on Amber's face as I said that. Then again maybe I was just paranoid. I didn't really trust that girl. No one else seemed to notice though, not even Sam, so I guess it really was just my imagination.

We spent the next half hour going from store to store, looking at tons of different clothes. While the others, Kelly in particular, seemed to be enjoying themselves, and bought a few outfits, I quickly realized that I could not get over my boredom. I tried to hide it and pretend I was interested, but it was useless. As I should have already learned, Sam could easily see right through me. She grabbed my hand and pulled me away from the group.

"I appreciate the effort, Ally, but it's obvious that you're not having fun." Sam said.

"I'm sorry, I tried, but I just can't enjoy this."

"You know, maybe you'd have more fun if you actually bought something." Sam suggested.

"Uh, I sort of... don't have any money. I'm totally broke. I just came here to hang out with you guys, wasn't planning on buying anything."

"Well if that's the problem, don't worry about it. Just pick something you like, it's on me."

"Thanks for the offer, but that's not the only problem. I'm just not really into clothes, or shopping. I still can't figure out why you guys enjoy it. Shopping has always been a chore to me."

Sam paused for a moment. Judging by the look on her face, she was trying to think up a solution, as if I was a puzzle that could just be solved. Then the metaphorical lightbulb appeared over her head.

"You're lying. Shopping isn't always a chore to you. It just depends on the circumstances. Tell me, do you like video games?"

"I play once in a while, but not that much."

"Music?"

"Again, just casually."

"Movies?"

And she hit her target. I did have a soft spot for cinema, and owned a sizable movie collection. And suddenly I knew where she was going. I liked buying movies. There was a certain thrill to be had searching through piles of Dvd boxes, and finding that one film that had been missing from my collection at a low price. Sam was right, everybody did like shopping, it just depended on what they were shopping for. If girls liked clothes the same way I liked movies, it suddenly made sense that they'd spend their free time at clothing stores. But there was still one major flaw in Sam's argument.

"I get your point." I said. "But movies and clothes aren't the same thing. And I'm only into one of those."

"Look, I don't like shopping either, but Kelly and Amber are my friends, and I do like hanging out with them. If you don't like clothes, at least you can enjoy the company. You're alone here."

Well, it's good to know that I'm not the only one who's bored here. At least... Wait a sec!

"Hold on, what did you just say?"

Sam froze, and for the first time since I met her, I could see through her as well as she could see through me. And I knew that she'd slipped up and said something she didn't mean to.

"Uh, I mean... Shopping! Yay!" Sam said, awkwardly.
1111111111111211111111111.title: Girl Activities 101

11111111111112111111111111.content:
"Let me get this straight. You invited me to go shopping, even though you knew I wouldn't like it. You basically guilt tripped me into coming here. And now, you tell me that you don't even like shopping? Why are we here, then?"

"Okay, first off, I didn't guilt trip you; you guilt tripped yourself." Sam answered. "Secondly... You're pretty much right about the rest. But look, coming here was Kelly's idea. I didn't object because... Well...?"

"Because what?"

"I'd rather not talk about it here. There are some things about me that Kelly and Amber don't know, and I'd like to keep it that way."

"Alright. I understand that. It's still kind of surprising. I never thought you were the tomboy type."

"Look, don't get me wrong. I love being a girl, I love wearing girl clothes. I just don't like shopping for them. That and a few other things."

I wasn't sure I understood. Why was she so ashamed of not liking shopping? Plenty of girls don't like shopping. Obviously, it wasn't the only reason. I'd have to talk to her about it later.

"Anyway, we've been talking for a while now. Kelly and Amber are probably wondering what's taking so long, so we should probably get back." Sam said. "My offer still stands, by the way. See anything you like, it's on me."

Once we got back to the rest of the group, Sam immediately started smiling again. She looked genuinely happy as we resumed our shopping, but I knew better. She was faking it. It was actually frightening how easily she could slip into a role like that. Of course, I'd attempted the same thig earlier, but Sam was infintely more convincing. Makes you wonder how much of her is real, and how much is an act.

Forcing myself to ignore my worries about Sam, I did eventually find an item I liked: a nice jacket that, somehow, represented me perfectly. It was a light blue color, simple, nothing frilly, but it did make me look... cute, I guess? Point is, it looked nice without looking overly girly, which is exactly the look I was going for. And it was inexpensive too, something Sam's wallet was thankful for.

About an hour later, we were all ready to go home. However, before we split up, Sam asked me if I could come to her place the next day after school. I accepted of course. It didn't take a genius to know what it was about.
11111111111112111111111111.title: Sam Explains (Story by Unknown Dude)

111111111111121111111111111.content:
"Well, this is it," said Sam. "This is my house."

Instead of going home after school like I usually did, I walked with Sam to her house. For some reason, she insisted on me not telling Kelly and Amber about it. Why was it so important? They've known Sam for years, surely they've been here plenty of times! Sam opened the door, told her mother that she had a friend with her (which seemed to surprise her), and then led me upstairs to a door at the end of the hallway.

"... And this is my room," she added.

"You still haven't told me why you wanted me to come over," I pointed out.

"Yeah, sorry about that. I just don't really know where to start. I guess it's better to show you."

On these words, Sam opened the door to her bedroom... revealing absolutely nothing I hadn't seen before. The room was a mess, with a pile of dirty clothes on the floor in the corner of the room, but otherwise there was nothing special about it. It looked pretty much like my own bedroom. I followed Sam inside, and that's when I started paying attention to the decoration. Like a normal girl's room, the walls were covered in posters... but they weren't the usual posters of celebrities. Rather, there were posters of various video games and horror movies. A quick look at her desk revealed a Alienware desktop that looked much more powerful than my own pitiful computer. In another corner was a small TV with a PlayStation 2 hooked up to it. Next to that, a pile of games and movies that looked far more interesting than what I'd seen at Melissa's apartment. And then I understood.

"You've never let Kelly and Amber inside your room, have you?" I asked.

"No... I always managed to find excuses to avoid it."

"But why? I didn't even know you liked video games!"

"That's kind of the idea," replied Sam. "I don't want Kelly and Amber to know that I like video games, or that I'd much rather watch a gory horror film than a chick flick, or that I don't really like shopping."

"But why don't you just tell them? Why can't you just be yourself?"

Sam sat on her bed, and I could see something was wrong. it brought back memories of that day in the hallway, when Sam found me crying. Except now our places were reversed.

"I already tried that. Before high school. I was a total nerd, and, well... the other girls didn't understand why I'd rather play Final Fantasy than talk about boys, and the guys wouldn't hang out with me because I wasn't one of them. I didn't really mind, because that meant I had a lot of time to myself. But then they started picking on me, and it didn't stop until high school. At that point, I realized I had to change. I became just like the other girls, I met Amber and Kelly, and I haven't had any problems since."

"So you're just going to keep lying to them? You never feel the need to be yourself?"

"Of course I do! That's why I keep my room like that and never let anyone else in. That's why I'm telling you all this!"

"But you barely know me! We've only been friends for a few days!"

"And yet you told me all about your problems back at school. You trusted me, and now I'm trusting you. You know, I met Amber pretty much the same way I met you: I found her crying in a hallway, but she never told me why. And Kelly just never talks about her problems, I'm not even sure she's ever had any. You're the only person who's ever really opened up to me. Of course it's not the only reason I'm telling you this..." Sam paused. She looked straight into my eyes, and it felt like she was "reading" me. "I know I can talk to you because you're the same as me. You know what it's like to not be like the other girls, to not really fit in. You can understand better than they can."

"I'm touched that you trust me that much," I started. "But I can't let you do this to yourself. You can't keep hiding like that forever, you'll go crazy! I know I would."

"I made it this far didn't I? I'm a pretty good actress. And I can keep track of who I am on the inside. Look, it's not a big deal, I can deal with all this. I just need one person I can talk to."

"Well, I guess you can talk to me. But I'm sure Kelly wouldn't ditch you if you showed her all this. She's been your friend for years, you can trust her!"

"Are you really so sure about that?" asked Sam. "What about Amber? I've known her for years too, and yet..."

She was right. I couldn't say how Kelly would react to learning her best friend wasn't who she thought she was. And Amber, regardless of how long she'd known Sam, really didn't seem trustworthy.

"So I guess that's pretty much it," concluded Sam. "It... feels good to get all that off my chest."

I looked around Sam's room, staring at the movie posters on her wall. She didn't like the same movies I did, but she certainly didn't have bad taste. She seemed to have a fondness for cult horror films. I looked at her pile of DVDs, where movies and games were mixed without any sort of organization. Titles included the likes of Dead Alive, Shin Megami Tensei, Army of Darkness and Fatal Frame. I wondered; if Sam was such a huge gamer, why didn't she upgrade to a PS3?

"Nice collection, huh?" said Sam. "I really like horror movies. Like, a lot. I'm also a huge fan of old-school survival horror and JRPGs, but... they just don't make them like they used to, so I switched to PC gaming."

"Uh-uh. That sure is impressive." By which I mean there was easily over a hundred DVD boxes in that pile. "You know, a lot of these movies are on my to-watch list."

"Well, how about we watch one right now?" Sam replied.

"Sure, that would be great!"

"Just.. sorry about the TV, it's really old." It looked like it came from the 90s. "I've been saving up for a new one, but I spent a bunch of money on a new video card."

"I don't mind, just pick a movie."

And, just like that, it suddenly felt like Sam and I would get along much better than I previously thought.

1111111111111211111111111111.content:
It had been fifteen days since I woke up back at the hospital. Fifteen days, and yet it felt like months... I missed the way things used to be. Living with Dad and Aaron, hanging out with Patrick and Eric, being a normal guy. The thought of forgiving them and going back home had passed through my mind a few times, but I couldn't bring myself to do it. Besides, my new life wasn't so bad. Living with Melissa was nice, as long as she wasn't insisting that I should be more feminine. I had new friends now. Kelly, Sam and Amber. Sam in particular was a lot of help. Over the past five days, we'd spent a lot of time together. We really understood each other. Things were finally starting to look up. Well, except for one detail...

"You know, you could have avoided this if you'd just do your laundry," said Melissa.

"I just don't think about stuff like that," I replied. "Come on, can't I just borrow a pair of pants?"

"We're not the same size, it wouldn't fit right. And it won't be so bad, you know."

"Of course not!" I said, sarcastically. "I'll just get laughed at by everyone who sees me."

"You're exaggerating, Ally."

"Okay, maybe they won't laugh, but they'll still comment on it, and it'll be awkward."

I took another look at my rapidly dwindling pile of clean clothes. It had gotten to the points where I didn't have any pants left to wear, so I'd have to wear a skirt. I knew I'd regret letting Melissa buy these. It seems like every day I get drawn a little further into femininity. Not much I can do about it, I guess. With Melissa clearly not inclined to help, I'll have no choice but to wear it.

"Alright, you win, I'll wear a skirt. You happy now?"

"You need to stop making such a big deal out of everything, Ally. You'll be much happier if you stop worrying about what people think of you. I'll let you get dressed, now. Just hurry it up a little, I'm gonna be late for work."

I settled on a denim skirt and a black t-shirt, and soon we were on our way to school. Once there, I half expected everyone to look at me and simultaneously burst out laughing, but of course it didn't happen. Why would they? My short lived celebrity had faded within the week, and now I was back to being just another high school kid. No one cared what I was wearing... and yet I still couldn't get the fact that I was in a skirt out of my head. It felt different than pants, and it kept bugging me throughout the day. I managed to deal with it until lunch break, when I had someone to meet.

"Hi Ally," said Eric. "It's been a while."

"We talked yesterday," I replied.

"That was on the phone. It doesn't count as a real conversation. I haven't seen you since last week."

We both sat in the staircase, which was located at the opposite side of the school from the cafeteria. A favorite spot of ours when we wanted to eat lunch without the ambient noise. It had been a while since I sat here...

"So, how's Patrick doing?" I asked.

"Fine. He didn't say anything about you... Why are you wearing a skirt?"

Damn it. I knew it would happen eventually.

"Not my fault. Well, it is, but..."

"Only thing you had left?" he asked, interrupting me.

"Yeah."

"Eh, not important. I don't know why you make such a big deal out of it."

"I don't... I don't make a big deal out of it! I didn't even mention it! And why did you ask me if it's not important?"

"You keep looking at it and tugging it down. Looks like it makes you uncomfortable. I was just wondering why you're wearing it if you don't like it. But it makes sense if you just didn't have anything else, so it's not important. Anyway, back to Patrick: he didn't say anything about you, but he doesn't talk much these days. It's like he's constantly in a bad mood. I told him he should talk to you, but he doesn't want to."

"So, what do you think I should do?"

"I think you should talk to him,” Eric deadpanned.

"After what he said to me last time? He tried to get involved in my personal problems. Things that are none of his business. I don't owe him anything."

Eric rolled his eyes, trying to make it as obvious as possible.

"Okay. I figured as much. But... what did you want to talk to me about, then?"

"Oh, right. I know we haven't talked much lately, and I feel kinda bad about it, so I figured we should hang out sometime. Also, I want you to meet my new friends. Well, mostly one of my new friends. One I think you'll get along with."

"You sure about that? Past experience has taught me that I don't get along with most people other than you and Patrick. But I'll trust you on that. Anyway, how about today after school? I've got nothing then."

"You know what, how about we just ditch school?” I suggested. “I’ve got PE this afternoon, and I don’t plan on actually going there. Been skipping it since school started, and the teacher hasn’t said anything. Let’s just catch a movie or something.”

“That works for me. It’s not like I ever learned anything I class. I’ll just read the textbook later.”

Typical Eric. How that guy isn’t failing is beyond me. Then again, he always gets better grades than I do. I looked down and noticed that I hadn’t even touched my lunch yet, despite being awfully hungry. I quickly gobbled my sandwich, after which Eric and I slipped out of the school unnoticed.

11111111111112111111111111111.title: Later

111111111111121111111111111111.content:
As we walked out of the movie theater as the credits were rolling, I found myself thinking hard about the last two hours. The movie wasn’t as good as we were hoping for, but I was almost more entertained by how Sam and Eric were acting. The two of them bought a large popcorn and drink to share, and they were quietly giggling throughout the movie as they whispered in each other’s ears. While I don’t think they would call it a date, by high school standards it might as well have been.

The three of us wondered around the mall for a while, occasionally going in a store to look around, but eventually leaving in the very late afternoon empty handed. After dropping Sam off at her house, Eric and I began the short drive to Melissa’s apartment. Along the way, I looked at Eric and said “Mind if I ask you a question?”

“Sure” he replied. “What’s up?”

“Do you like Sam?”

“Oh course I do. Your friends are my friends. Besides, she gave me her gamer tag” he said, clearly misunderstanding what I had asked.

“No, that’s not what I meant. I mean, do you like her” I said, trying to put as much emphasis on the word like to get my point across.

“Oh, um” he stuttered.

“Oh my gosh. You do like her” I shouted, a little bit of surprise in my voice.

“I don’t know” he replied. “I mean, she’s a cool person and all that. Plus we like a lot of the same stuff”

“So, are you going to ask her out?” I asked.

“I don’t know” he answered. “Maybe. After I get to know her better. Can we talk about something else please?”

“Sure” I replied. We spent the rest of the drive talking about school, namely a project Eric had where he was going to have to do a bulk of the work if he and his partner were going to get a good grade. It wasn’t long before we were pulling into the parking of Melissa’s apartment complex and I told Eric that I would see him Monday at school.

With my backpack over one shoulder, I made my way up the stairs that lead to Melissa’s apartment. It was on the third floor, so there was quite a few stairs that I had to ascend. While I climbed the stairs I thought about what I should do this weekend. Melissa had told me that she planned on making the invitations for her wedding this weekend, so it was probably inevitable that I’d be helping her with that.

I took out the key that Melissa had given me when I moved in, but discovered the door to be unlocked already. “Mel, I’m home” I shouted as I walked in. I was immediately greeted by a sight that I both didn’t want to or expect to see, as I saw my father sitting on the couch with Melissa. “What are you doing here” I said as I stopped in my tracks.

“I came to talk to you” he said. “And to apologize”

“Apologize for what” I asked. “For completely erasing the person I used to be from existence. I’m sorry but I don’t think I’ll be able to accept that”

“No. That’s not it” dad replied. “Aaron told me what you said at school and I wanted to apologize for how you found out about your new identity. You deserved to be told to your face rather than hear it through a closed door. And I wanted to apologize for all the pain and anger it caused you. You’ve been given an amazing opportunity through this second chance and so far you’ve spent most of it angry with me”. He paused for a moment to see if I had anything to say before continuing. “Now, if your willing I want to take a chance to explain what it is you heard that night”

“There’s nothing to explain” I nearly shouted. “You erased who I was from the face of the earth”

“No, Allison. That’s not at all what I did” he replied. “Every paper and document that identifies you as having once been Brian is still there. But while you were in the hospital I began the process of having your new identity connected to your old one. Your birth certificate still says you were born Brian Samuels, it will just be in a folder that says Allison now”

“So, your saying that you didn’t completely erase who I used to be” I replied as I took a seat next to him.

“I didn’t erase a thing” he said. Suddenly, and unexplainably, I had a massive urge to hug my dad. I could feel tears forming in my eyes. I had effectively kicked my dad and brother out of my life over a misunderstanding. Without warning I threw my arms around my dad and broke down crying. I’m not sure how many times I said I was sorry for the way I had been treating him and Aaron the past few days. He in turn told me he completely understood given what I thought I knew.

We stayed at Melissa’s for a few hours more as we packed up the few things I had there and said our goodbyes. Once we left I had a fairly lengthy conversation. While Aaron had been keeping dad somewhat up to date with how I had been doing in school, but he still had no idea how I'd been handling the change. Once we arrived at home and brought my stuff in the house I instantly went looking for Aaron, finding him in his room playing video games. I knocked on his door, and once he paused his game and saw me standing in the doorway his jaw nearly fell on the floor. To say he wasn't expecting to see me was an understatement. I was surprised he was as willing to accept my apology as he was, given how I'd been treating him at school. His only condition on accepting my apology was that we get as caught up this weekend on all the video game time we missed while I was in the hospital.

The two of us played games late into the night. Sometime around 1:30 in the morning we began getting tired, so I decided that it would be a good time to go to bed. After stripping out of my clothes, I grabbed one of my old shirts that were hanging in the closet and a pair of my old boxers. The shirt was for all intents and purposes a dress on me now that I was so much shorter, and the boxers were stretched out more than they were used to thanks to my much larger butt. But I was able to put that out of my mind as I crawled in between my sheets given how tired I was. However, as I lye there I couldn't help but think about how much more comfortable my bed was compared to the futon I had been sleeping on at Melissa's.

Playing video games with Aaron cooled what bad blood remained from the spat in the kitchen. I enjoyed yelling at the screen, trying to beat my brother to the best gun upgrade, shooting him down and tea-bagging his space marine character with glorious laughter, all like I was still a sixteen-year old, immature boy, not a curvy, teenage girl some nurses had mistook for a grown woman.

After Dad got home, I dawdled in my room, catching up with my friends' lives through Facebook. My name, profile picture, and personal information still listed me as Brian, but I figured I'd change it another time. I'd traded out Rachel's ultra-femme outfit for some of my old clothes, which I begged Dad to bring just in case, they might make good pajamas or something. I wore a Black Sabbath t-shirt that wouldn't fit except my breasts compensated for the thinner torso, and boxers as long as fall shorts. I'd thrown the bra and panties on the floor, and while my nipples sometimes brushed the cotton and stung, it felt worlds better. Rachel told me to wear feminine clothing every day my first month to break the prejudice and help me get comfortable; I wondered what she'd say if I told her my brother eyed me like a wolf. How about those feminine clothes now?

Around nine I figured I should wash myself. I didn't want Aaron to see me undress or naked so I checked the bathroom lock before disrobing, then turned the water pressure really high so everywhere in the house, you could tell someone was about to take a bath. There would be no misunderstanding, no knocking on the door, saying, "Oh! I didn't know you were in there!" and catching a peek of my cleavage. Even I'd grown wary of looking at my body; I stared ahead while undressed and avoided the mirror until I got in the bath. Then I stretched out in the water till only my head was visible. Admittedly, the water tickled my nether regions in a way I slightly enjoyed, I won't stress it too much, but it helped me close my eyes, blow bubbles with my mouth, and forget the day's troubles.

Then someone pounded on the door.

"What the hell?" I snapped, splashing everywhere, disturbed from my zen-bath. I gripped the edges to lift myself, but a grumbly voice said, "Don't move! You can keep washing, I got the keys."

I settled back in. It was my dad. The doorknob jiggled while he put the key in, then the door swung open and Dad walked in, tie hanging like a scarf on his neck, dress shirt unbuttoned, and specks of salsa around his lips. Good ol' Dad, I thought, Don't change after work, just kick back and watch the tube, eating nachos. I didn't think this in a negative way. I loved my dad, laziness and all.

"Don't mind me, uhh... Alyssa." He nodded to himself; yeah, he'd said the right name. "I won't be long, but I wanted to talk."

I sank deeper. You could only see me from the nose up. "Mmhm?" I gurgled.

"Aaron told me about what happened with you guys earlier, when you were doing dishes and he, looked from behind--"

"Yeah, Dad, I know what happened," I said, treading water with my left leg. I refused to make eye contact with my dad; not while we discussed this.

"He told me he apologized, and you accepted it. I hope you really did, but that's not why I'm here right now..." Dad took a deep breath. I finally looked at him, and saw he was straining to say whatever he intended to tell him. "It's a good time to ask yourself, now that you're out..."

info.description:
Brian Samuels is your typical 16 year old boy; a Junior in High School with some close friends. One day he's playing basketball in the driveway; when he's hit by a passing truck.

He comes out of a medically induced coma 6 months later to find that the only way for him to survive was to be made into a girl.

The following is the story of how he copes and learns to adapt to his new life and gender.

Characters:
1. Brian Samuels (You): 16 years old; Junior in High School. Best friends with Patrick Sullivan and Eric Greyson. As a girl, goes by the name Allison
2. Aaron Samuels: 15 years old; sophomore in High School. Doesn't know how to cope with his older brother being a girl.
3. Kevin Samuels: 38 years old; widower and father of Brian and Aaron. Unsure of how to raise a daughter; having only raised 2 boys.
4. Kelly O'Rourke: 15 years old; girl that Aaron has feelings for. Decides to befriend Allison and help her adjust
5. Samantha Paterson: 15 years old; friend of Kelly's. Follow's Kelly in support of Allison.
6. Amber Riley: 15 years old; friend of Kelly and Samantha's. Doesn't accept that Allison's a girl and torments her.
7. Aubrey Mitchell: 18 years old: sophomore in High School. Also doesn't accept Allison as a girl and wants to hurt her. Closeted bisexual.
8. Brianna Wallace: age unknown. Strange bisexual girl with an unpleasant gay sister Rose. On and off girlfriend of Patrick Sullivan. Feature also in Garage Sale of Change (http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-IHSvEWJaZXs/T_c-_I4qUkI/AAAAAAAAABk/lERNkjARaFA/s1600/...)
